data.note: The state utility, Zesco, has operations in generation, transmission, distribution and retail, and controls the majority of electricity in these areas. There are a few companies that provide independent generation and retail. Sector liberalisation in the 1990s meant that it would be legally possible for a private company to run transmission or distribution networks. The Copperbelt Energy Corporation is one example, running a transmission grid in the north of the country (see the Zambia Energy Regulation Act).
data.name: The power sector has been unbundled (whether privatized or not) into distinct actors for generation, transmission, distribution and retail

data.note: There are a handful of private generators, and Copperbelt Energy Corporation runs a transmission grid. The state utility, Zesco, is also involved at each stage.
data.name: There are legally separate private companies at each segment of the power system pre-retail

data.note: Transmission is largely controlled by the state-owned utility, Zesco. There is no independent system operator.
data.name: There is an independent transmission system that dispatches according to market dynamics and is not susceptible to state interference

data.note: Electricity prices are heavily subsidised. One of the major challenges for the energy sector is handling the transition to cost-reflective tariffs. First, working out what the true cost of generation is, and second, managing the transition.
data.name: Retail electricity prices aren't distorted by subsidies

data.note: Securing PPAs with Zesco as a private company is notoriously difficult, a lengthy and bureaucratic process. The country's 'Scaling Solar' tenders, run by Zesco's owner, the IDC, will bypass this and should speed up the process.
data.name: There aren't significant barriers to private sector participation in generation

data.note: There are a few opportunities to buy power direct from independent power producers for people in the right areas, but it is often not a direct choice.
data.name: Consumers can choose retail suppliers or third-party power marketers in the retail power market

data.note: Power is either generated by Zesco or purchased from IPPs under bilateral contracts.
data.name: There is a functioning competitive wholesale generation market

data.note: Zesco controls the majority of generation in the country.
data.name: The generation market has many different actors and is not concentrated in the hands of a few players

data.note: Zesco controls the majority of supply in the country.
data.name: The supply market has many different actors and is not concentrated in the hands of a few players
